body_html:
That looks like a different problem: the code in your model_fn is attempting to pass an (apparently nested) dictionary of tensors to tf.shape(), which expects a tensor. I think part of the problem is in your input_fn where you wrap next_example (which is already a dict mapping 'sgram' to a tensor) in another dictionary:

    return {'sgram': next_example}, next_label

Instead, you should be able to do:

    return next_example, next_label

That looks like a different problem:  the code in your model_fn is attempting to pass an (apparently nested) dictionary of tensors to tf.shape(), which expects a tensor. I think part of the problem is in your input_fn where you wrap next_example (which is already a dict mapping 'sgram' to a tensor) in another dictionary:
    return {'sgram': next_example}, next_label
Instead, you should be able to do:
    return next_example, next_label
body:
That looks like a different problem:  the code in your `model_fn` is attempting to pass an (apparently nested) dictionary of tensors to `tf.shape()`, which expects a tensor. I think part of the problem is in your `input_fn` where you wrap `next_example` (which is already a dict mapping `'sgram'` to a tensor) in another dictionary:

```python
    return {'sgram': next_example}, next_label
```

Instead, you should be able to do:

```python
    return next_example, next_label
```
